content.json:
[ Add Company Logo ]

# Azure Kubernetes Service - Example

This dashboard provides insights into [ Customer ] Azure Kubernetes Environment. This workbook is an example to help show the capabilities for monitoring AKS in Azure. 


> To use this workbook you must have Container Insights enabled on your cluster.

### Documentation

- [Azure Service Status](https://status.azure.com/en-us/status)
- [AKS Monitoring Guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/monitor-aks)
- [Availability Testing](https://github.com/ms-sambell/app-insights-private-availability-tests)
- [Container Insight Queries](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/containers/container-insights-log-query)
- [AKS Troubleshooting Guide](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/containers/container-insights-troubleshoot)
- [AKS Troubleshooting - error messages](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/azure/azure-kubernetes/welcome-azure-kubernetes)

parameters.name: LogAnalyticsWorkspace
parameters.label: Log Analytics Workspace
parameters.query:
resources
| where type =~ "Microsoft.OperationalInsights/workspaces"
| project id, name

content.query: {"version":"AzureHealthQuery/1.0","queryType":"Detailed"}
content.title: AKS Cluster Health

content.json:
# Changes (Kube Audit)

Kubernetes captures audit logs for all activities in the cluster. However, it needs to be explicitly enabled. Once these logs are enabled and published to a Log Analytics workspace they can be queried. 

The audit logs show who deleted, patched or created new resources. Which is incredibly useful when troubleshooting issues. 




> The query below depends on the `Log Analytics Workspace` parameter specified for this parameter. 

- **[Kubernetes Audit Logs - Azure](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/aks/monitor-aks-reference#resource-logs)**

content.query:
AzureDiagnostics
| where Category in ("kube-audit-admin", "kube-audit")
| project TimeGenerated, ResourceId, log_s
| extend eventMessage = parse_json(log_s)
| extend K8Event = parse_json(eventMessage.objectRef)
| project TimeGenerated, eventMessage.verb, K8Event.name, username = eventMessage.user.username, K8Event, eventMessage
| where eventMessage_verb !in ("post", "get")
| where username !in ("aksService", "aksProblemDetector", "")
| where username !has "system:"
| project TimeGenerated, Action = eventMessage.verb, Resource = K8Event.name, Namespace = K8Event.namespace, KubernetesResource = K8Event.resource, Username = eventMessage.user.username
content.title: Kubernetes Audit Logs
content.noDataMessage: No user initiated events happened within the cluster (check the log analytics workspace selected is correct).

content.json:
## Change Analysis

All changes in Azure are captured by the `Activity Logs` (audit trial). These logs can be tricky to parse, so there's a new way to view this data (Change Analysis). 

> *Note:* this resource provider may need to be enabled in your subscription.

content.query: {"version":"ChangeAnalysis/1.0","changeLevels":["Important","Normal"]}
content.title: AKS Cluster Changes
content.noDataMessage: No changes made to the AKS cluster

content.json:
# Service Health

Provides insights into Azure service outages, planned maintenance activities and service health.

### Event Types:

- **Maintenance**: Planned or Unplanned maintenance events.

- **ServiceIssue**: Issues related to service performance or downtime.

- **HealthAdvisory**: General advisory information about services.

[More Information](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-health/overview)

content.query:
ServiceHealthResources
| where type =~ 'Microsoft.ResourceHealth/events'
| extend eventType = properties.EventType, status = properties.Status, description = properties.Title, trackingId = properties.TrackingId, summary = properties.Summary, priority = properties.Priority, impactStartTime = properties.ImpactStartTime, impactMitigationTime = todatetime(tolong(properties.ImpactMitigationTime)), eventLevel = properties.EventLevel
| where  tolong(impactStartTime) > 1
| where todatetime(impactStartTime) {Timerange}
| extend StartTime = todatetime(impactStartTime)
| project impactStartTime, StartTime, eventLevel, status, description, eventType, summary, trackingId
| summarize arg_max(todatetime(impactStartTime), StartTime, tostring(eventLevel), tostring(status), tostring(description), tostring(eventType), tostring(summary)) by tostring(trackingId)
| order by StartTime
//| summarize by todatetime(impactStartTime), tostring(eventLevel), tostring(status), tostring(description), tostring(eventType), tostring(summary)

parameters.name: alertResourceGroups
parameters.label: Resource groups
parameters.query:
Resources
| summarize by resourceGroup
| order by resourceGroup asc
| project id=resourceGroup, resourceGroup

parameters.name: alertResourceTypes
parameters.label: Resource types
parameters.query:
where "*" in ({alertResourceGroups}) or resourceGroup in ({alertResourceGroups})
| summarize by type
| project type, label=type

parameters.name: alertResources
parameters.query:
Resources 
| order by name asc
| extend Rank = row_number()
| project value = id, label = name, selected = Rank <= 10, group = resourceGroup

content.json:
# Alerts

Alerts within your Azure environment by severity that are active within the environment.

content.query:
AlertsManagementResources | where type =~ 'microsoft.alertsmanagement/alerts'
| where todatetime(properties.essentials.startDateTime) {Timerange} 
| extend State=tostring(properties.essentials.alertState)
| where "*" in ({State}) or State in ({State})
| summarize Count=count(), New=countif(State=="New"), 
Acknowledged=countif(State=="Acknowledged"), 
Closed=countif(State=="Closed") 
by Severity=tostring(properties.essentials.severity)
| order by Severity asc
content.title: Alert Summary

content.query:
AlertsManagementResources 
| where type =~ 'microsoft.alertsmanagement/alerts'
| where todatetime(properties.essentials.startDateTime) {Timerange}  
| extend Severity=tostring(properties.essentials.severity)
| where Severity in ({Severity})
| extend State=tostring(properties.essentials.alertState)
| where "*" in ({State}) or State in ({State})
| project AlertId=id, StartTime=todatetime(tostring(properties.essentials.startDateTime)), Severity, State=tostring(properties.essentials.alertState), MonitoringCondition=tostring(properties.essentials.monitorCondition), Name=name, 
  TargetResource = tostring(properties.essentials.targetResource), 
  MonitorService = tostring(properties.essentials.monitorService),
  SignalType=tostring(properties.essentials.signalType), 
  Description=tostring(properties.essentials.description)
| order by StartTime desc
content.title: {$rowCount} {Severity} Alerts

content.query:
AlertsManagementResources | where type =~ 'microsoft.alertsmanagement/alerts'
| where todatetime(properties.essentials.startDateTime) {timeRange}  
| extend Severity=tostring(properties.essentials.severity)
| where Severity in ({Severity})
| extend State=tostring(properties.essentials.alertState)
| where "*" in ({State}) or State in ({State})
| where "*" in ({ResourceTypes}) or properties.essentials.targetResourceType in~ ({ResourceTypes})
| where "*" in ({ResourceGroups}) or properties.essentials.targetResourceGroup in~ ({ResourceGroups})
| where "*" in ({Resources}) or properties.essentials.targetResource in~ ({Resources})
| summarize Alerts=count(), New=countif(State=="New"), 
Acknowledged=countif(State=="Acknowledged"), 
Closed=countif(State=="Closed")
by Resource=tostring(properties.essentials.targetResource )
| order by Alerts desc
content.title: {Severity} Alerts by Region

content.json: ðŸ’¡ Select one or more regions to see Azure resources with alerts in those regions.

content.query: {"version":"1.0.0","content":"[{Selected}]","transformers":null}
content.title: Resources with {Severity} Alerts in the Selected Regions

content.json:
# Resource Health

Information about the health of individual cloud resources. Resources can be in the following states:

- **Available**: There's no events detected that are affecting the health of he resource.

- **Unavailable**: The service detected an ongoing platform or non-platform event affecting the health of the resource.

- **Unknown**: No information has been received in the last 10 minutes for this resource.

- **Degraded**: Performance loss detected for the resource, but it is still avaialble.

[More Information](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-health/resource-health-overview)

content.query: {"version":"AzureHealthQuery/1.0","queryType":"Detailed"}

content.json:
# Events

Every action in a Kubernetes cluster generates an event. Events are critical to understanding issues with the resources running in an Azure Kubernetes Cluster. 

By default the `container insights` add-on will only capture **warning** events (to Modify this review the [Data Collection Settings](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-monitor/containers/container-insights-agent-config) documentation).

- **[What are Events](https://www.cncf.io/blog/2021/12/21/extracting-value-from-the-kubernetes-events-feed/)**

content.query:
KubeEvents
| project Name, Namespace , ObjectKind, Reason, Message, Computer//, KubeEventType, _ResourceId
| summarize count() by ObjectKind
content.title: Failed Events by Object Kind

content.query:
KubeEvents
| project Name, Namespace , ObjectKind, Reason, Message, Computer//, KubeEventType, _ResourceId
| summarize count() by Reason
content.title: Failed Events by Reason

content.query:
KubeEvents
| project Name, Namespace , ObjectKind, Reason, Message, Computer//, KubeEventType, _ResourceId
| summarize count() by Namespace
content.title: Failed Events by Namespace

content.query:
KubeEvents
| project TimeGenerated, Name, Namespace , ObjectKind, Reason, Message, Computer//, KubeEventType, _ResourceId
| order by TimeGenerated
content.title: Failed Events Detailed View

content.json:
# Workloads

Within Kubernetes containers can run in different workload types. All containers run in a **Pod** but pods can be managed by different **controllers**. Below outlines information on pods and deployments (most common workload type).

content.query:
InsightsMetrics
| where Name == "kube_deployment_status_replicas_ready"
| extend Details = parse_json(Tags)
| project Deployment = Details.deployment, Namespace = Details.k8sNamespace, Requested = Details.spec_replicas, Available = Details.status_replicas_available,   TimeGenerated
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, Deployment, Namespace, Requested, Available) by tostring(Deployment), tostring(Namespace),tostring( Requested), tostring(Available)
| order by toint(Available) asc
content.title: Deployment Summary

content.query:
InsightsMetrics
| where Name == "kube_deployment_status_replicas_ready"
| extend Details = parse_json(Tags)
| project Deployment = Details.deployment, Namespace = Details.k8sNamespace, Requested = toint(Details.spec_replicas), Available = toint(Details.status_replicas_available),   TimeGenerated
| summarize count( toint(Available) == 0 ) by tostring(Deployment), bin(TimeGenerated, 5m)
content.title: Deployments with 0 available Replicas

content.query:
KubePodInventory
| where PodStatus !in ("Running", "Succeeded")
| project TimeGenerated, Name, _ResourceId, ContainerStatus, Namespace, PodStatus, ControllerName
| summarize count() by ControllerName, bin(TimeGenerated, 10m)
content.title: Pod - Non Running State
content.noDataMessage: No pods are in a non-running state

content.query:
KubePodInventory
| where PodStatus !in ("Running", "Succeeded")
| project TimeGenerated, Name, _ResourceId, ContainerStatus, Namespace, PodStatus, ControllerName
| summarize count() by ControllerName, PodStatus, ContainerStatus
| order by count_
content.title: Pod - Non Running State
content.noDataMessage: No pods are in a non-running state

content.json:
# Logs

By default when an application logs to **STDOUT** or **STDERR** the message will be captured by Azure Container Insights and ingested into Log Analytics.

content.query:
KubePodInventory 
|project ContainerID, Name, ServiceName, ControllerName
| join kind=inner
(ContainerLog
| project LogEntry, TimeGenerated, _ResourceId, ContainerID) on ContainerID
| extend ServiceName = iff(isempty(ServiceName), ControllerName, ServiceName)
| project ServiceName, LogEntry, TimeGenerated
| summarize count() by ServiceName
| order by count_
content.title: Log Count by Pod

content.query:
KubePodInventory 
|project ContainerID, Name, ServiceName, ControllerName
| join kind=inner
(ContainerLog
| project LogEntry, TimeGenerated, _ResourceId, ContainerID) on ContainerID
| extend ServiceName = iff(isempty(ServiceName), ControllerName, ServiceName)
| where ServiceName in ("{ServiceName}") or "{ServiceName}" == "empty"
| project ServiceName, LogEntry, TimeGenerated, _ResourceId
| summarize count() by ServiceName, bin(TimeGenerated, 10m)
content.title: Log Count by Pod

content.json:
# Pod Logs

Logs should be structured and any multi-line log messages should appear in a single `LogEntry` row. 

- **ServiceName**: The name of the controller (e.g. deployment)
- **Investigate Errors**: To Investigate issues use the `open in search` button in the top right corner of the Log Output Panel.

> **Note:** Select a ServiceName in the `Log Count by Pod` panel above to filter the logs to just that service.

content.query:
KubePodInventory 
|project ContainerID, Name, ServiceName, ControllerName
| join kind=inner
(ContainerLog
| project LogEntry, TimeGenerated, _ResourceId, ContainerID) on ContainerID
| extend ServiceName = iff(isempty(ServiceName), ControllerName, ServiceName)
| where ServiceName in ("{ServiceName}") or "{ServiceName}" == "empty"
| project ServiceName, LogEntry, TimeGenerated, _ResourceId
| summarize count() by ServiceName, LogEntry, _ResourceId
| order by count_
content.title: Log Count by Pod Log Output

content.json:
# Nodes

Nodes in Kubernetes are the Virtual Machines where the containers will run. If the Nodes are unhealthy or there's not enough nodes available it will impact workloads running in the cluster.

content.query:
KubeNodeInventory
| where Status !in ( "Ready", "")
| project TimeGenerated, Status, Computer
| order by TimeGenerated
content.title: Unhealthy Nodes

content.json:
## Cluster Autoscaling

If your cluster has autoscaling enabled it will scale out the Nodes dynamically. 

> This panel only works if the Cluster Autoscaler diagnostic logging is enabled. 

- **unschedulable**: This is referring to Pods who can't start due to resource constraints (a trigger to scale)
- **No expansion options**: The NodePool can't scale anymore (max scale size).
- **Requested scale-up **: Autoscaling triggered (request sent to VMSS)

content.query:
AzureDiagnostics
| where Category == "cluster-autoscaler"
| extend trimmed_log = trim_start(@"^.*?\]\s+", log_s)
| where trimmed_log has "is unschedulable" or trimmed_log has "No expansion options"  or trimmed_log has "unneeded" or trimmed_log has "removal" or trimmed_log has "unregistered nodes present" or trimmed_log has "Unschedulable pods are very new, waiting one iteration for more" or trimmed_log has "Best option to resize" or trimmed_log has "Estimated" or trimmed_log has "Requested scale-up" or trimmed_log has "increase scale set" 
| project TimeGenerated, trimmed_log
content.title: Cluster Autoscaling
content.noDataMessage: Ensure the correct Log Analytics Workspace is selected. If empty, there's no scaling events.
